Comment: Mini Tournament match, this is our second game of the tournament, score 1-0 favoring me. This game I'm black, and my opponent gets some payback. I open with the Sicilian.

And there it is, black's big blunder. 34. ... f6? was a mistake that guarantees a draw. Consolodating the queen, inching the pawns forward, looking for queen exhantes, trying to create a passed pawn, trying not to let white get in front of it and hold onto a draw - that's what black should have done. Instead, I did this...

White forked two pawns. Worse is the threat of forced checkmate in 3 starting with 37. Qf8+ Kh5 38. g4+ Kh4 39. Qh6# unless black stops it right now, leaving his pawns out to die.

Black has two pawns hanging, which one will white kill?
Black has two pawns hanging, which one will white kill?

I think white might have made the wrong decision. Taking the pawn at h7 gives white a passed pawn. Maybe he can find a way to promote, maybe not, but after capturing at h7, black will be playing for a draw. But by capturing at e6, now black is the one who will get a passed pawn and it will be white playing for a draw. Either way, both lines would likely be draws, but it seems better to put your opponent on the defensive rather than the other way around. Black forces the queen exchange and gains his passed pawn.
